page.title: 18WILD LIFE OF THE LOWLAND
page.content: TO THE NORTH-WEST OF MARGROVE PARK THERE IS AN AREA OF LAND WHICH HAS BEEN UNDERMINED BY THE IRONSTONE MINES AND THE LAND HAS SUNK CAUSING A LARGE POND AND MARSHY LAND. THE POND ATTRACTS WATERFOWL, INCLUDING MUTE SWANS. THE BIRDS ATTRACTED BY THE VEGETATION OF THE MARSHLAND INCLUDE; WILLOW AND SEDGE WARBLERS AND REED BUNTINGS. BULL, GREEN, GOLD AND CHAFFINCHES: RED POLLS, MAGPIES, JAYS, CROWS, ROOKS; LITTLE, TAWNY AND LONG-EARED OWLS; BLACKBIRDS, THRUSHES, SPARROWS, ROBINS AND WRENS CAN ALL BE SEEN AROUND THE AREA. SMOOTH NEWTS, FROGS AND TOADS ALSO LIKE THE MARSH AREA. COMMON BUTTERFLIES; LARGE, GREEN-VEINED AND SMALL WHITES, SMALL TORTOISESHELL, RED ADMIRAL, PEACOCK AND PAINTED LADIES CAN ALL BE SEEN IN FAVOURABLE CONDITIONS IN SEASON.
